doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
#Symptoms#
(1) Paroxysmal limb twitching for the past 14 days.
(2) Tonic twitching of limbs during sleep, accompanied by foaming at the mouth and loss of consciousness, lasting for about 1 minute.
(3) Confusion, gibbering, and irritability after convulsions.
(4) Headache symptoms after antiviral and intracranial pressure-lowering treatment.
(5) Fever and headache 16 days ago, with the highest temperature of 37.8°C, and tested positive for the new coronavirus.

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Brain MRI showed abnormal signals in the left frontal lobe.
(2) Electroencephalogram (EEG) showed abnormal brain activity, consistent with a seizure disorder.
(3) Video EEG showed epileptiform waves emanating from the left side.
(4) Lumbar puncture results were normal, ruling out viral encephalitis and cerebral vasculitis.
(5) Blood tests showed no abnormalities.
(6) Repeat brain MRI showed no significant changes in the abnormal signals in the left frontal lobe.

#Diagnosis#
Focal epilepsy

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) The patient's symptoms of paroxysmal limb twitching, tonic twitching of limbs during sleep, and confusion after convulsions are consistent with a seizure disorder.
(2) The EEG results showed abnormal brain activity, consistent with a seizure disorder.
(3) The video EEG results showed epileptiform waves emanating from the left side, indicating a focal origin of the seizures.
(4) The lumbar puncture results were normal, ruling out viral encephalitis and cerebral vasculitis.
(5) The repeat brain MRI showed no significant changes in the abnormal signals in the left frontal lobe, indicating a stable lesion.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Antiepileptic medication: Start with levetiracetam, 500mg twice daily, and adjust the dosage based on the patient's response to the medication.
(2) Regular follow-up appointments: Schedule regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's response to the medication and adjust the dosage as needed.
(3) Lifestyle modifications: Advise the patient to avoid triggers that may exacerbate their seizures, such as sleep deprivation, stress, and alcohol consumption.
(4) Seizure diary: Encourage the patient to keep a seizure diary to track the frequency and severity of their seizures.
(5) Safety precautions: Advise the patient to take safety precautions to prevent injury during a seizure, such as avoiding activities that could be dangerous if a seizure were to occur, such as swimming or driving.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed lumbosacral stiffness without obvious triggers 20 years ago. There is no fever, rash, dry mouth, dry eyes, blurred vision, heel pain, abdominal pain, diarrhea, frequent urination, urgent urination, or amphiphilia. He was diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis in a tertiary hospital in Beijing and received oral treatment of sulfasalazine enteric-coated capsules and subcutaneous injection of antibody fusion protein injection (Yisaipu). Two years ago, he was switched to Yisaipu alone for treatment, and his condition became stable. A month ago, her symptoms worsened after catching a cold, and she was admitted to the hospital with the diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis.

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Ankylosing spondylitis, thoracic vertebra compression fracture, hypertension grade 1
reference_diagnosis.basis:

reference_diagnosis.treatment:

4. Symptomatic analgesic treatment with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
5. Antibody fusion protein ** injection 50mg is injected subcutaneously once a week to control the progression of the disease.
6. Patient education.

#Symptoms#

(1) The patient has a 10-year history of hypertension, with the highest blood pressure recorded being 140/90mmHg.
(2) The patient is currently taking Lipitor 10mg/night and Norvax 5mg/day, and their blood pressure is controlled at 110-130/70-85mmHg.

#Auxiliary Examinations#

(1) Blood test results show an elevated level of C-reactive protein, which is a marker of inflammation.
(2) X-ray of the spine shows signs of ankylosing spondylitis, including fusion of the vertebrae and narrowing of the joint spaces.
(3) MRI of the spine shows inflammation in the sacroiliac joints and the spine.

#Diagnosis#

Ankylosing spondylitis with worsening symptoms.

#Diagnostic Basis#

(1) The patient has a history of ankylosing spondylitis and has been receiving treatment for it for 20 years.
(2) The patient's symptoms have worsened in the past month, and the X-ray and MRI results show signs of ankylosing spondylitis.
(3) The blood test results show an elevated level of C-reactive protein, which is a marker of inflammation.

#Treatment Plan#

(1) Continue taking Yisaipu for the treatment of ankylosing spondylitis.
(2) Consider adding a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) to help manage pain and inflammation.
(3) Encourage regular exercise and physical therapy to maintain mobility and flexibility.
(4) Monitor blood pressure regularly and adjust medication as needed to maintain control.
(5) Follow up with a rheumatologist for ongoing management of ankylosing spondylitis.

#Symptoms#
(1) Fatigue after activity for more than 2 years, significantly worsened in the past week
(2) No other accompanying symptoms, but poor mental state and diet recently

(2) Thyroid function tests are normal

(4) Sleep study shows no signs of sleep disorders
(5) Mental health assessment indicates mild depression

#Diagnosis#
Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS) and mild depression

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) The patient has experienced fatigue after activity for more than 2 years, which has significantly worsened in the past week.
(2) The patient has no other accompanying symptoms, but their mental state and diet have been poor recently.
(3) The CBC, thyroid function tests, vitamin and mineral levels, and sleep study results are all normal.
(4) The mental health assessment indicates mild depression.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Lifestyle modifications: Maintain a regular sleep schedule, engage in regular physical activity, practice stress-reduction techniques, and maintain a healthy diet.
(2) Psychotherapy: Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and support groups can help manage symptoms and improve mood.
(3) Medications: Antidepressants, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), can help improve mood and energy levels. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can help reduce pain and inflammation.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed chest tightness, shortness of breath, and occasional palpitations after exerting himself 6 months ago, but the symptoms resolved spontaneously. Symptoms have worsened in the past week, accompanied by fatigue and decreased activity tolerance. There was no syncope, nausea, vomiting, or precordial pain. The electrocardiogram from another hospital showed atrial fibrillation, and the ejection fraction on cardiac color Doppler ultrasound was 35%. The patient was given coronary enlargement, anti-platelet, lipid-lowering, and anti-heart failure treatments in the outpatient clinic. However, the symptoms persisted, so he was admitted to the hospital. There was no fever, cough, sputum production, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea or lower limb edema. He can eat well, has normal bowel movements, and has no significant change in weight.

- Echocardiography:
  - Left atrial diameter: 58×50 mm
  - Inner diameter of right atrium: 51×45 mm
  - Left ventricular end diastolic diameter: 58 mm
  - Mitral and tricuspid regurgitation: trace-mild
  - Aortic valve degeneration
  - Reduced left ventricular diastolic function
  - Decreased overall left ventricular systolic function (ejection fraction EF: 34%)
- Holter ECG:
  - Ectopic rhythm
  - Atrial fibrillation with fast ventricular rate (average heart rate 105 beats/min)
  - T wave changes
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Alcoholic cardiomyopathy and cardiac insufficiency (cardiac function class II)
2. Cardiac arrhythmia atrial fibrillation
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. The patient has a history of smoking and drinking, chest tightness, shortness of breath, and cardiac color ultrasound ejection fraction of 35%.
2. Physical examination showed irregular heartbeat, varying heart sounds, and electrocardiogram showed atrial fibrillation.
3. The patient has risk factors for coronary heart disease and has chest tightness and shortness of breath after activity. Coronary heart disease cannot be ruled out.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient was given treatment to reduce the preload and postload of the heart, including recombinant human natriuretic peptide, furosemide, spironolactone, sacubitril valsartan, dapagliflozin, metoprolol succinate, aspirin, clopidogrel, and rivaroxaban. Coronary CTA showed no stenosis. Considering alcoholic cardiomyopathy, dual anti-antibody was stopped, and anti-heart failure treatment was continued. Before discharge, EF increased to 54%, and the diagnosis was revised to alcoholic cardiomyopathy.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
#Symptoms#
(1) Intermittent chest tightness and shortness of breath for the past 6 months, worsening over the past week.
(2) Fatigue and decreased activity tolerance.
(3) Occasional palpitations after exertion.
(4) No history of syncope, nausea, vomiting, or precordial pain.
(5) No fever, cough, sputum production, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, or lower limb edema.
(6) No history of hypertension, coronary heart disease, or diabetes.
(7) Long-term alcohol consumption of about 250 ml of liquor per day.

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) ECG showed atrial fibrillation.
(2) Echocardiogram confirmed an ejection fraction of 35%.
(3) Stress test showed that heart rate and blood pressure increased appropriately during exercise, but chest tightness and shortness of breath were experienced.
(4) Blood tests showed no signs of infection or electrolyte imbalances.

#Diagnosis#
Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) due to atrial fibrillation and long-term alcohol consumption.

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Symptoms of chest tightness, shortness of breath, fatigue, and decreased activity tolerance.
(2) Echocardiogram confirmed an ejection fraction of 35%, indicating reduced heart function.
(3) ECG showed atrial fibrillation, which can contribute to heart failure.
(4) Long-term alcohol consumption can also contribute to heart failure.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Continue current medications for coronary enlargement, anti-platelet, lipid-lowering, and anti-heart failure treatments.
(2) Consider reducing or stopping alcohol consumption to improve heart function.
(3) Consider referral to a cardiologist for further management and follow-up.
(4) Encourage lifestyle modifications such as regular exercise, a heart-healthy diet, and stress management techniques.
(5) Consider additional medications or interventions as recommended by a cardiologist.

#Diagnosis#
Coronary heart disease

#Diagnostic Basis#

(2) The patient has been experiencing recurrent chest pain for the past 6 years, with a recent increase in chest tightness for the past half month.
(3) The patient has experienced shortness of breath and palpitations along with the chest pain.
(4) The coronary angiography showed that there is some blockage in the coronary arteries.

(2) Medications, such as aspirin, statins, beta blockers, and other drugs to lower blood pressure and cholesterol levels.
(3) Procedures or surgery, such as angioplasty, stent placement, or coronary artery bypass surgery, may be necessary to improve blood flow to the heart.
(4) Regular follow-up appointments with a healthcare provider to monitor the patient's condition and adjust the treatment plan as needed.

(4) Abdominal ultrasound to check for any abnormalities in the liver or other organs.

Acute viral hepatitis

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) The patient's symptoms of fatigue, yellow urine, and reduced urination volume are consistent with acute viral hepatitis.
(2) The patient's history of recurring headaches and occasional epigastric pain may also be related to acute viral hepatitis.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) The patient should avoid alcohol and any medications that may affect liver function.
(2) The patient should undergo liver function tests (LFTs), complete blood count (CBC), urinalysis, and abdominal ultrasound to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity of the disease.
(3) The patient should be monitored closely for any signs of liver failure or other complications.
(4) The patient may require antiviral therapy or supportive care depending on the severity of the disease.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient began to experience palpitations without obvious triggers 1 month ago. They were paroxysmal and worsened after activity. They lasted for about 10 minutes each time and relieved on their own after resting. Accompanied by mild shortness of breath, there are no other symptoms such as chest pain, dizziness, nausea, and cough. There has been no significant change in weight recently. She went to our hospital for treatment due to symptoms. The electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm with frequent ventricular premature beats (bigeminy). Chest CT showed small nodules in the upper lobe of the right lung. Troponin I was normal. The diagnosis on admission was "premature ventricular contractions".
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Electrocardiogram (05.16): Sinus rhythm, frequent premature ventricular contractions (bigemy).
- Chest CT: small nodular shadow in the upper lobe of the right lung, and enhanced texture in both lungs.
- Troponin I(05.21): Normal.
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Arrhythmia: Frequent premature ventricular contractions.
Cardiac function class II (NYHA classification).
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient complained of palpitations, and physical examination revealed an irregular heartbeat with frequent premature ventricular contractions, which was confirmed by an electrocardiogram. There were no obvious cardiac structural abnormalities and troponin I was normal, ruling out acute myocardial infarction. Based on symptoms, signs and auxiliary examination results, premature ventricular contractions were diagnosed. Heart function class II is based on the patient's mild shortness of breath after activity and mild limitation of physical activity.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient was given myocardial nutrition therapy (trimtazidine, dibutyryl, energy mixture), vital signs were monitored, and oxygen was inhaled. Coronary angiography showed no significant stenosis and good left ventricular function (EF79%). After treatment, the symptoms improved and he was discharged.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
#Symptoms#
(1) Intermittent palpitations for the past month, worsening after physical activity, lasting for about 10 minutes, and resolving on their own after resting.
(2) Mild shortness of breath, but no other symptoms such as chest pain, dizziness, nausea, or cough.

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm with frequent ventricular premature beats (bigeminy).
(2) Chest CT showed small nodules in the upper lobe of the right lung.
(3) Troponin I levels were normal.
(4) Echocardiogram showed no structural abnormalities in the heart.
(5) Holter monitor test showed frequent ventricular premature beats, consistent with the electrocardiogram findings.
(6) Pulmonary function tests were normal.
(7) Blood tests showed no electrolyte imbalances or other abnormalities.

#Diagnosis#
Premature Ventricular Contractions (PVCs)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) The patient's symptoms of intermittent palpitations and mild shortness of breath.
(2) The electrocardiogram and Holter monitor test results showing frequent ventricular premature beats.
(3) The echocardiogram showing no structural abnormalities in the heart.
(4) The pulmonary function tests being normal.
(5) The blood tests showing no electrolyte imbalances or other abnormalities.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Lifestyle Modifications: Avoiding triggers such as caffeine, alcohol, and stress can help reduce the frequency of PVCs. Regular exercise and a healthy diet can also improve heart health.
(2) Medications: If lifestyle modifications are not enough to control your symptoms, medications such as beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers may be prescribed to slow down the heart rate and reduce the frequency of PVCs.
(3) Follow-up: Regular follow-up appointments with your doctor are important to monitor your symptoms and adjust your treatment plan as needed.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient was found to have bilateral thyroid masses through color ultrasound one year ago, with the left side being larger and painless. There were no other symptoms of hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism. Recently, the mass on the left side of the neck has increased. Color ultrasound showed that the left lobe of the thyroid gland is occupying space, which is considered malignant. The cervical lymph nodes are swollen and partially calcified. The neck mass was punctured and dark red fluid was aspirated, and a biopsy was recommended. The patient's general condition is good and there is no obvious weight loss.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Color ultrasound examination
  - Space-occupying left thyroid lobe with sandy calcification, TI-RADS category IV C
  - Multiple swollen lymph nodes on the left side of the neck with some calcifications
  - Right thyroid lobe nodule, TI-RADS category III
- Fine needle aspiration
  - 2 ml of dark red liquid was aspirated, and scattered epithelial cells were seen. The possibility of thyroid follicular epithelium was considered, and nuclear grooves were visible in some parts.
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Left thyroid gland cancer (T2N1M0), right benign nodule.
reference_diagnosis.basis: Based on the medical history, physical examination and auxiliary examination results, it is considered that the left lobe of the thyroid gland may be malignant and the right lobe nodule may be benign. Intraoperative rapid pathology showed thyroid cancer on the left side and no clear tumor tissue on the right side. Paraffin pathology further confirmed that the left thyroid gland had ovarian cancer, with a mass size of 2cm × 2cm × 1cm, and tumor tissue metastasis in the left central area and cervical lymph nodes. The right thyroid gland is an adenoma.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient completed relevant examinations, including blood routine, thyroid function, liver and kidney function, blood sugar, electrolytes, coagulation function, electrocardiogram, chest X-ray, etc. No abnormalities were found. CT neck showed space occupying the left lobe of the thyroid gland and enlarged lymph nodes in the left neck. Preoperative preparation was sufficient, and left thyroid lobe + isthmus resection + right subtotal thyroidectomy was performed. The patient recovered well after the operation and was given fluids, electrolytes and hemostatic treatment. The sutures were removed and discharged after 10 days of hospitalization.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
#Symptoms#
(1) The patient has noticed a mass on the left side of their thyroid for about a year now, which has recently grown larger.
(2) The patient has no other symptoms of hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism and is generally in good health.

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Thyroid function tests (TFTs) show normal thyroid hormone levels.
(2) Thyroid ultrasound confirms the presence of bilateral thyroid masses, with the left side being larger and painless. The left lobe of the thyroid gland is occupying space, which is considered malignant. The cervical lymph nodes are swollen and partially calcified.
(3) Fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy shows that the thyroid mass is malignant.
(4) Calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels are within normal limits.
(5) Anti-thyroid antibodies are negative.

#Diagnosis#
Thyroid cancer

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) The patient has a mass on the left side of their thyroid that has grown larger over time.
(2) Thyroid ultrasound confirms the presence of bilateral thyroid masses, with the left side being larger and painless. The left lobe of the thyroid gland is occupying space, which is considered malignant. The cervical lymph nodes are swollen and partially calcified.
(3) Fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy shows that the thyroid mass is malignant.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Surgery to remove the thyroid gland and any affected lymph nodes.
(2) Radioactive iodine therapy to destroy any remaining cancer cells.
(3) Thyroid hormone replacement medication for the rest of the patient's life.
